Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
About the Course
“Performance of Networked Systems”
Class essentially consists of two parts:
1. Performance engineering for networked client applications
2. Performance modelling for servers and networks
Background reading material:
1. Book “High Performance Browser Networking” by
Grigorik (available online via CANVAS)
2.

networked client applications
2. Performance modelling for servers and networks
Background reading material:
1. Book “High Performance Browser Networking” by
Grigorik (available online via CANVAS)
2. Reader “Stochastic Performance Modeling” by
O.J. Boxma
3. Individual papers
Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Course Elements
• Lectures (2x per week)
• One homework assignment
• Register groups via CANVAS
• Written exam 
• Self study (with the book and the reader)
• Grading: exam (80%) + homework (20%)
• exam grade must be > 5.5 for passing the course

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
“End-to-End” Performance of
Networked Systems
• User - and hence the business - cares about response time
• How much of it is caused by:
• the server(s)?
• the network?
• the client?
• the interactions among client, network, and servers?
• Often called end-to-end response time
?
Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Influence of the clie

the client?
• the interactions among client, network, and servers?
• Often called end-to-end response time
?
Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Influence of the client side is often overlooked:
• How much processing is done at the client side?
• on a mobile device, or a rusty old computer 
• The interaction between client and server is often critical
• over mobile networks
Classical “performance work” is about capacity planning:
• Focus on server throughout and make sure they can handle 
the clients’ requests (within the SLA), during peak load
Client, Server and Network Performance
“Network performance” is often misinterpreted and over-rated:
• “I have 10Gb/s access”, but what do you really get?
• Network performance often confused with access bandwidth

understand the basics of networking

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Bandwidth-Delay Product (BDP)
• Flow control in place to avoid overloading the receiver
• Window size = number of not yet acknowledged packets 
• BDP = bandwidth x RTT = maximum congestion window size

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Bandwidth is Overrated
• It is relatively simple to increase bandwidth
• e.g., use more than one link in parallel
• optical fiber is improving, and so are wireless technologies
• In the Internet core, a single optical fiber can handle 
400 wavelengths with 171 Gbit/s per channel, in total 
>70 Tbit/s

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
It's the Latency, Stupid!
Components of delay (also known as “latency”)
• propagation delay (signal propagation, depending on physical
distance)
• transmission delay (packet length / bandwidth)
• processing delay (time required to process a packet like framing, 
forwarding)
• queueing delay (time a packet waits in queues)

Lecture 1: Introductio

transmission delay (packet length / bandwidth)
• processing delay (time required to process a packet like framing, 
forwarding)
• queueing delay (time a packet waits in queues)

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Signal Latencies
• Signal latency is determined by the laws of physics
• We can not do anything about that
• Speed of light in vacuum: 3 x 108 m/s
• Speed of light in fiber/copper: 2 x 108 m/s

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Packet Latencies in Practice
• Signal latencies cover physical distance only
• Actual wires follow longer paths due to geographic, political, or even commercial 
reasons
• each hop (router) on the path adds processing overhead
• In practice, the RTT between New York and Sydney is more li

res follow longer paths due to geographic, political, or even commercial 
reasons
• each hop (router) on the path adds processing overhead
• In practice, the RTT between New York and Sydney is more like 200-300 ms, rather 
than 160 ms (still pretty good)

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
• While global links (e.g. undersea cables) show latency close to 
physical signal propagation, the connection from customers to their 
ISP add significant latency
• “Last mile” problem
• Other measured latencies over wired technologies:
• fiber-to-the-home: 18 ms
• TV cable: 26 ms
• DSL: 44 ms
Last Mile Latency

Lecture 1: Introduction to communication networking © Rob van der Mei
Low Bandwidth at the Network Edge
How to deal with low bandwidth (“work arounds”)?
• use data compression → send less data
• reduce networking overhead → example: selective acknowledgments
• use caching: store “local” copies to avoid

Human Perception of Delay
1. Humans notice delay of 100-200 ms
2. > 300 ms is reported as “sluggish” 
3. > 1000 ms make users think about other things

Lecture 2: Introduction to performance modeling © Rob van der Mei
OSI Model and TCP/IP Stack
OSI model TCP/IP model
• The OSI model is a conceptual framework using which the functioning of a network 
can be described (theoretical, for education purposes, to understand networking)
• The TCP/IP model is a 4-layer practical model, forms the basis for the Internet, built 
on specific protocols (TCP, UDP and IP), actually used for I

for education purposes, to understand networking)
• The TCP/IP model is a 4-layer practical model, forms the basis for the Internet, built 
on specific protocols (TCP, UDP and IP), actually used for Internet communication
• The TCP/IP stack is a concrete implementation of the TCP/IP model

Probability Distributions
• Continuous random variables
– can have any real value (not restricted to 
integer)
– typical examples:
• time between successive breakdown events
• waiting time, job processing time, response time in 
RTS
• Discrete random variables
– can have only integer values
– typical examples:
• number of job arrivals in given time interval
• number of system failures in given time interval

Properties of Exponential Distribution
Memoryless property: fundamental!
• Example:
• X := lifetime of a component
• Prob{ X > 30 | given X > 10 } = Prob{ X > 20 }
• information about “past” no influence on future
• “used is a good as new”

Poisson Process
• Poisson process is a stochastic process (with rate λ)
• Inter-arrival (IAT’s) times should satisfy following two requirements
1. mutually independent
2. exponentially distributed (each with the same mean 1/λ)
• Poisson process models “completely random” events
• natural way to model human-initiated events
– occurrence of rare events (for example in real-time systems)
– customers arriving at a post office
– initiation o

Probability Distributions
• Continuous random variables
– can have any real value (not restricted to integer)
– typical examples:
• time between successive breakdown events
• waiting time, job processing time, response time in RTS
• Discrete random variables
– can have only integer values
– typical examples:
• number of job arrivals in given time interval
• number of system failures in given time interval

Processor Sharing Models
Processor Sharing (PS): If k customers in the system, then each
of them gets processing speed 1/k (“fair sharing”)
Key performance metric: mean sojourn time E[S] (models the 
transfer time of a flow)
This model is often called the “M/M/1” PS model
• 1st “M” means “Markovian” (Poisson), 2nd “M” exponential service times, and 1 means 1 server

• Non-conforming packets are marked (e.g., discarded, or given low-priority)

The way leaky bucket policing works:
1.When burst rate > policing rate => water level in the bucket rises
2.When water volume = burst tolerance (that is: “the bucket is full”) only a fraction “f” of the packets are 
marked conforming and the other packets as non-conforming
3.Fraction conforming “f” is given by f = policing rate / peak rate, and fraction non-conforming by 1-f = 
(peak rate – policing rate) / peak rate
